author: Eduardo Ordax
authorHeadline: ü§ñ Generative AI Lead @ AWS ‚òÅÔ∏è (100k+) | Startup Advisor | Public Speaker | AI Outsider
text:
üî• Learning CUDA in 12 hours?! Yes and it‚Äôs brutal‚Ä¶ but absolutely essential.

If you‚Äôre serious about building a career in AI, I mean building AI, not just with it, then you can‚Äôt afford to ignore CUDA.

CUDA is where the magic happens and what makes AI run‚Ä¶.It‚Äôs the invisible backbone behind everything from training LLMs to fine-tuning models and optimizing inference on GPUs.

üí° The good news?
There‚Äôs now a free, 12-hour deep dive course that covers all the fundamentals.
It‚Äôs intense. It‚Äôs technical. It can be painful but it‚Äôs worth every minute.

üß† You‚Äôll learn:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Deep learning ecosystem + CUDA setup
2Ô∏è‚É£ GPU programming & writing your first kernels
3Ô∏è‚É£ Kernel profiling, atomics & the CUDA programming model
4Ô∏è‚É£ cuBLAS, cuDNN, and when to use them
5Ô∏è‚É£ Matrix multiplication optimization (yes, really)
6Ô∏è‚É£ CUDA vs Triton ‚Äî which one to use, when
7Ô∏è‚É£ PyTorch extensions & low-level hacks
8Ô∏è‚É£ Building an MLP trainer from scratch ‚Äî in PyTorch, NumPy, C‚Ä¶ and finally CUDA üòÆüí®

üìÖ My advice?
Don‚Äôt binge it in one go. Set a pace: 3 hours/week, finish in a month. Take notes. Rebuild the examples.

Let‚Äôs go deep. Links to the course in the comments!

#AI #CUDA #NVIDIA #LLMs
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Yves Albers-Schoenberg
authorHeadline: Founder & CTO at Roboto AI
text:
ùóôùóøùóºùó∫ ùó•ùó¢ùó¶ ùòÅùóº ùóüùó≤ùó•ùóºùóØùóºùòÅ: ùóõùóºùòÑ ùóîùóøùó≤ ùóßùó≤ùóÆùó∫ùòÄ ùóõùóÆùóªùó±ùóπùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó©ùóüùóî ùóóùóÆùòÅùóÆ ùó£ùó∂ùóΩùó≤ùóπùó∂ùóªùó≤ùòÄ?

Most real-world robotics systems are built on pub/sub architectures like #ROS.
Sensors and estimators publish asynchronously and at different rates:

‚Ä¢ Cameras at ~30 Hz
‚Ä¢ Perception at ~10 Hz
‚Ä¢ State, control, and actions all run on their own clocks

This decoupled design has powered robotics for decades. Vision-Language-Action models like NVIDIA Robotics GR00T and Physical Intelligence pi0 work differently. For both training and inference, they require synchronized, tensor-based data with aligned observations, states, and actions on a shared timeline.

Hugging Face's #LeRobot has emerged as the community standard for representing this kind of training data. It is PyTorch-native, well documented, and increasingly supported across the ecosystem.

The hard part is the bridge from asynchronous ROS topics to synchronized LeRobot episodes, without introducing bias or artifacts.

At Roboto AI, we see a few common approaches in practice:

1) ùó•ùóÆùòÑ ùó•ùó¢ùó¶ùóØùóÆùó¥ ùóºùóø ùó†ùóñùóîùó£, ùòÅùóµùó≤ùóª ùóºùó≥ùó≥ùóπùó∂ùóªùó≤ ùó∞ùóºùóªùòÉùó≤ùóøùòÄùó∂ùóºùóª ùòÅùóº ùóüùó≤ùó•ùóºùóØùóºùòÅ
‚úî Maximum data fidelity and the ability to reprocess later
‚úò Timestamp handling, resampling, interpolation, and episode definition all need real care

2) ùó¢ùóªùóπùó∂ùóªùó≤ ùòÄùòÜùóªùó∞ùóµùóøùóºùóªùó∂ùòáùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùòÑùó∂ùòÅùóµ ùó±ùó∂ùóøùó≤ùó∞ùòÅ ùóüùó≤ùó•ùóºùóØùóºùòÅ ùòÑùóøùó∂ùòÅùó∂ùóªùó¥
‚úî Training-ready data immediately
‚úò Synchronization choices are locked in once data is recorded

3) ùóõùòÜùóØùóøùó∂ùó± ùó∞ùóÆùóΩùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤ ùòÇùòÄùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóøùóÆùòÑ ùóØùóÆùó¥ùòÄ ùóΩùóπùòÇùòÄ ùóÆ ùòÄùòÜùóªùó∞ùóµùóøùóºùóªùó∂ùòáùó≤ùó± ùó±ùóÆùòÅùóÆùòÄùó≤ùòÅ
‚úî Fast iteration with reproducibility
‚úò Higher storage costs and more operational complexity

4) ùóñùòÇùòÄùòÅùóºùó∫, ùóªùóºùóª-ùó•ùó¢ùó¶ ùóΩùó∂ùóΩùó≤ùóπùó∂ùóªùó≤ùòÄ
‚úî Full control over data primitives
‚úò You end up re-implementing large parts of the robotics stack

The most common failure mode we see is train-inference skew between offline preprocessing and live data flow. This problem exists across ML, but it becomes especially critical when observations map directly to robot actions.

Typical causes include:

‚Ä¢ Different resampling or alignment logic
‚Ä¢ Implicit lookahead during offline conversion
‚Ä¢ Episode boundaries that do not match deployment

The result is strong offline metrics and disappointing real-world behavior.
Despite the push toward end-to-end learning, most production robots will continue to rely on ROS-style pub/sub systems for the foreseeable future. That makes reproducible and auditable data curation the key link between robotics stacks and VLA training.

At Roboto, we are actively building tooling to go from raw robotics data to ML-ready datasets. If you are working on VLA pipelines and have wrestled with this gap, I would love to compare notes.
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Jim Fan
authorHeadline: NVIDIA Director of AI & Distinguished Scientist. Co-Lead of Project GR00T (Humanoid Robotics) & GEAR Lab. Stanford Ph.D. OpenAI's first intern. Solving Physical AGI, one motor at a time.
text:
Introducing NitroGen, an open-source foundation model trained to play 1000+ games: RPG, platformer, battle royale, racing, 2D, 3D, you name it! We are on a quest for general-purpose embodied agents that master not only the real world physics, but also all possible physics across a multiverse of simulations.

We found that our GR00T N1.5 architecture, originally designed for robotics, can be adapted easily to play lots of games with wildly different mechanics. Our recipe is simple and bitter lesson-pilled: (1) a 40K+ hour, high-quality dataset of public in-the-wild gameplay; (2) a highly capable foundation model for continuous motor control; (3) a Gym API that wraps any game binary to run rollouts.

Our data curation is a lot of fun: it turns out that gamers love to show off their skills by overlaying real-time gamepad control on a video stream. So we train a segmentation model to detect and extract those gamepad displays and turn them into expert actions. We then mask out that region to prevent the model from exploiting a shortcut. During training, a variant of GR00T N1.5 learns to map from 40K hours of pixels to actions through diffusion transformers.

NitroGen is only the beginning, and there's a long way to hill-climb on the capability. We intentionally focus only on the System 1 side: the "gamer instinct" of fast motor control. We open-source *everything* for you to tinker: pretrained model weights, the entire action dataset, code, and a whitepaper with solid details.

Today, robotics is a superset of hard AI problems.
Tomorrow, it might become a subset, a dot in the much larger latent space of embodied AGI. Then you just prompt and "ask for" a robot controller.

That might be the end game (pun intended).

NitroGen is co-led by our brilliant minds: Loic Magne, Anas Awadalla, Guanzhi Wang. It's a multi-institutional collaboration.

Website: https://lnkd.in/geiNxkq9
Paper: https://lnkd.in/gbufppAW
Code: https://lnkd.in/gRGDnnpy
Pretrained model weights: https://lnkd.in/gNangU74
Action dataset: https://lnkd.in/gW36UJpy
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Marc Mayol Orell
authorHeadline: Generative AI Tech Lead y Profesor
text:
Los sistemas agentic parecen magia‚Ä¶ hasta que se rompen en producci√≥n: r√°pido, ruidoso y caro. Muchos ‚Äúagentes‚Äù hoy son demos pegadas con cinta y una API key, sostenidas por hype y por fe.

Construir con agentes ahora a veces se siente como montar una nave espacial con piezas de IKEA, sin manual y con el despegue en marcha: cada semana aparece un framework nuevo, y los equipos persiguen la estabilidad como un espejismo.

La buena noticia: el caos no es inevitable si lo abordas como arquitecto/a de sistemas. Si dise√±as pensando en escala, observabilidad y gobernanza (no solo en que ‚Äúfuncione en la demo‚Äù), el juego cambia.

Un mapa pr√°ctico en 9 capas para ordenar el stack agentic:

0) Despliegue: d√≥nde viven y se ejecutan los agentes (Groq, AWS Bedrock, Vertex AI, Modal)
1) Evaluaci√≥n y telemetr√≠a: medir para mejorar (LangSmith, DeepEval, Weights & Biases)
2) LLM core: el ‚Äúcerebro‚Äù (GPT-4o, Claude 4, Gemini 2.5, Llama 4)
3) Orquestaci√≥n: coordinaci√≥n de flujos y estados (LangGraph, CrewAI, AutoGen, Semantic Kernel)
4) Planificaci√≥n: descomposici√≥n y estrategia (Voyager, MetaGPT, CAMEL, OpenDevin)
5) Ejecuci√≥n de herramientas: funciones, APIs, b√∫squeda (LangChain Tools, OpenAI Functions, E2B)
6) Memoria y contexto: continuidad y recall (Zep, Memo, Reverie, PromptLayer)
7) Coordinaci√≥n y mensajer√≠a: que ‚Äúhablen‚Äù y se sincronicen (Kafka, Redis Pub/Sub, AgentHub)
8) Supervisi√≥n y gobernanza: l√≠mites, pol√≠ticas y control humano (Guardrails AI, LangFuse, PolicyKit)

Los tools cambian. La arquitectura aguanta. Y la gobernanza es lo que permite escalar algo m√°s all√° del prototipo.

Si est√°s conectando piezas sin un dise√±o claro, el coste aparece despu√©s: en incidentes, deuda t√©cnica y p√©rdida de confianza.

¬øQu√© capa est√°s trabajando m√°s ahora mismo: evaluaci√≥n, memoria, orquestaci√≥n, gobernanza‚Ä¶? Me interesa comparar enfoques y aprendizajes reales.
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: üéß Eric Riddoch
authorHeadline: Director of ML Platform @ Pattern
text:
Re: vibe coding. I had an interview today where they had me write a full-stack app in one hour. 

Tests. Backend. Frontend. Database. Docker.

Totally open book: Google, ChatGPT, cursor, Claude code, your personal project repos. All of it.

If not for my dabbling with vibe coding for work and personal projects, I would have been totally hosed. 

As it was, since I don‚Äôt have a full-time job, I don‚Äôt have ChatGPT or Cursor/Copilot so I scrambled to get onto the free versions of both. I managed to get a broken frontend working, basic backend with FastAPI and uv, and a redis cache in docker compose which I was proud of.

But I could have gotten further if I‚Äôd had one of my AI tools ready to go. Was the first interview ever where I found myself stress prompting instead of stress ‚Äúlooking for the index error on line 7.‚Äù

I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if I don‚Äôt pass the round since I could see how others would wreck my progress with the right tools and know how.

But it was fun!! I had a great time, and I‚Äôd love to run that sort of interview myself down the line.

Anyway, just watched this video about many Claude code features. The thing about git work trees would have helped me a ton today, I could have had a few agents in parallel, 

1. one debugging my frontend,
2. one writing pytest tests for the backend
3. one writing a playwright test for the static HTML, CSS, JS frontend 
4. one getting my uv docker build to work.

Anyway, this video has the quality of a well-written chapter of a book and it picked up a few tips from it: https://lnkd.in/gAZps5TN
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Jure Leskovec
authorHeadline: Professor at Stanford Computer Science and Co-Founder at Kumo.ai
text:
The AI Revolution for Structured Data is Finally Here.
Thrilled to share my conversation at The Data Exchange with Ben Lorica ÁΩóÁëûÂç° on a game-changing topic: Relational Foundation Models (RFMs).

For years, applying AI to enterprise's most valuable structured data (warehouses, customer records, transactions) has been stuck in manual feature engineering, taking months to deploy a single model. Not anymore.

Key Takeaways from the Discussion:
üß† No-Pipeline Predictions: RFMs treat relational data as a graph, allowing a pre-trained transformer to make instantaneous, zero-shot predictions (like 60-day churn or next-best-offer) directly from raw data in milliseconds.
üìà "Superhuman" Accuracy: Fine-tuned RFMs are delivering 10-20% higher accuracy than traditional ML approaches‚Äîleading to hundreds of millions in value for companies like DoorDash, Reddit, and Coinbase.
‚è±Ô∏è 20x Productivity: Data scientists are freed from the 6-month feature engineering treadmill to focus on business impact and strategy.

If you are a Data Scientist, ML Engineer, or Data Leader, this is essential listening to understand how the foundational model paradigm is coming to your data warehouse.

Listen to the full episode and check out the transcript below!
https://lnkd.in/drqEkjch
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Juan Mar√≠n
authorHeadline: CTO/Co-fundador | Arquitecto de Software. Construyendo 2 startups en Latam. Comparto el impacto de nuestras decisiones en el equipo y el negocio.
text:
ùóïùóøùòÇùóªùóº ùóµùóÆùó∞ùó≤ ùóπùóº ùóæùòÇùó≤ ùó£ùóºùòÄùòÅùó∫ùóÆùóª ùóªùòÇùóªùó∞ùóÆ ùóΩùòÇùó±ùóº

Bruno es un cliente de APIs open-source que finalmente lo hace bien: tus colecciones de APIs viven como ùóÆùóøùó∞ùóµùó∂ùòÉùóºùòÄ ùó±ùó≤ ùòÅùó≤ùòÖùòÅùóº ùóΩùóπùóÆùóªùóº en tu repositorio de Git.

Sin cuentas en la nube. Sin problemas de sincronizaci√≥n. Sin pagar licencias por cada usuario.

ùóïùóøùòÇùóªùóº ùó≥ùòÇùóªùó∞ùó∂ùóºùóªùóÆ ùó±ùó∂ùó≥ùó≤ùóøùó≤ùóªùòÅùó≤:

Guarda todo en una carpeta de tu sistema de archivos usando un lenguaje de marcado llamado ùóïùóøùòÇ. Esto significa que tus colecciones de APIs son simplemente archivos que puedes hacer commit, diff y merge como cualquier otro c√≥digo.

ùóüùóÆùòÄ ùòÉùó≤ùóªùòÅùóÆùó∑ùóÆùòÄ ùòÄùóºùóª ùó≤ùóªùóºùóøùó∫ùó≤ùòÄ:
‚Ä¢ Sin limite de usuarios. Sin pago de licencias por cada usuario. Todo tu equipo puede usarlo sin costos extra.
‚Ä¢ Colaboraci√≥n real basada en Git. Nada de "comparte este workspace".
‚Ä¢ Code reviews para cambios en APIs. Ves exactamente qu√© endpoints cambiaron en un PR.
‚Ä¢ Offline-first. Cero dependencia de servidores en la nube o autenticaci√≥n.
‚Ä¢ Sin telemetr√≠a ni env√≠o de datos a servidores de Bruno. Sin recolecci√≥n de datos personales, sin harvesting de informaci√≥n.
‚Ä¢ Funciona perfectamente con los workflows de Git que ya usas (branches, PRs, resoluci√≥n de conflictos).

ùó¶ùóºùóΩùóºùóøùòÅùó≤ ùó∞ùóºùó∫ùóΩùóπùó≤ùòÅùóº:

Soporta todo lo que esperar√≠as: REST, GraphQL, GRPC, WebSockets, variables de entorno, pre-request scripts, tests, OAuth 2.0, e incluso secret managers como HashiCorp Vault.

(Postman recientemente tambi√©n agreg√≥ sincronizaci√≥n con Git, pero usa JSON en lugar del formato Bru amigable de Bruno)

https://docs.usebruno.com/

Es lo que los clientes de APIs deber√≠an haber sido desde el principio.

author: Milvus, created by Zilliz
authorHeadline: 10¬†mil seguidores
text:
ùêëùêûùêùùêùùê¢ùê≠ ùêÑùêßùê†ùê¢ùêßùêûùêûùê´ùê¢ùêßùê† just shared a deep dive on their Vector Database selection journey.
Thrilled and honored to see ùêåùê¢ùê•ùêØùêÆùê¨ stand out for reliability and scale. üöÄ

They narrowed the field from many options (Vertex AI, Elasticsearch, etc.) to a final showdown: Qdrant vs. Milvus, based on strict criteria: Open Source, Proven 1B+ Scale, and High Performance.

üß™Reddit stressed-tested both systems, focusing on two critical operational areas:
1. ùêíùêúùêöùê•ùê¢ùêßùê†: While Qdrant required manual sharding for replication changes, Milvus excelled with ùêöùêÆùê≠ùê®ùê¶ùêöùê≠ùê¢ùêú ùêùùêöùê≠ùêö ùê´ùêûùêõùêöùê•ùêöùêßùêúùê¢ùêßùê†, significantly reducing operational toil.
2. ùêÉùêûùêõùêÆùê†ùê†ùêöùêõùê¢ùê•ùê¢ùê≠ùê≤: Reddit found that Milvus's distributed architecture provided superior observability and control, making it easier to isolate and fix issues under stress.
This is precisely why Reddit chose ùêåùê¢ùê•ùêØùêÆùê¨üèÜ.

üí°There is no "standard answer" for selection, but here are some lessons learned:
ùêÉùê¢ùê† ùêÉùêûùêûùê©ùêûùê´: Challenge requirements and avoid bias‚Äîdon't get trapped by existing solutions.
ùêíùêúùê®ùê´ùêûùê¨ ‚â† ùêÉùêûùêúùê¢ùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêßùê¨: Use matrices to clarify needs, but don't get fooled by flashy documentation.
ùêÅùêöùê•ùêöùêßùêúùê¢ùêßùê† ùêÄùê´ùê≠: Don't obsess over raw speed. Prioritize maintenance, debugging, and usability over niche performance metrics.

author: Alejandro Saucedo
authorHeadline: AI & Tech Executive @ Zalando | Advisor @ UN, EU, ACM, etc | Join 70k+ ML Newsletter
text:
Sebastian Raschka and Andrej Karpathy's educational material is becoming a key cornerstone for foundational ML knowledge; and Raschka's recent course on "Building an LLM (From Scratch)" is becoming a must-watch classic: 

This course walks ML practitioners through implementing a GPT-style model end-to-end in plain PyTorch, starting from text preprocessing and tokenization. 

It goes through hand-built attention and Transformer blocks to a full GPT architecture with training and generation which is great to build the intuition. 

Along the way in this course, you implement next-token pretraining on unlabeled text, and then repurpose the pretrained backbone for supervised tasks like text classification and simple chat-style behavior. 

There are quite a lot of great takeaways, but these approaches of learning by building something from scratch often are such a great way to develop the foundations before going to the higher level / advanced domains (i.e. building agentic frameworks, transfer learning, etc). 

Course: https://lnkd.in/ecMjKvqn 

‚Äî

If you liked this post you can join 70,000+ practitioners for weekly tutorials, resources, OSS frameworks, and MLOps events across the machine learning ecosystem: https://lnkd.in/eRBQzVcA

text:

F√°cil y esencial para entornos distribuidos.

Si no sabes qu√© es un bloqueo exclusivo:
üî∫ Da acceso de solo escritura a un recurso.
üî∫ Impide leer y escribir a otros procesos.

Solo necesitas tener Docker instalado.

Lo que haremos ser√°:
üî∏ Levantar Redis en local usando Docker.
üî∏ Conectar a Redis desde Python.

author: Deedy Das
authorHeadline: Partner at Menlo Ventures | Investing in AI startups!
text:
üö®China's DeepSeek just dropped the only open-source model good enough at math to win IMO Gold, and a must-read report!

The key idea draws from things Karpathy and others have spoken about: move beyond ‚Äúfinal answer RL‚Äù into a generator‚Äìverifier‚Äìmeta-verifier loop in pure language.
‚Äì A verifier is RL-trained to score proofs.
‚Äì A meta-verifier checks the verifier‚Äôs critiques.
‚Äì A generator is RL-trained on verifier reward signals to write and self-check better proofs.

Because everything lives in natural language (no Lean), this recipe SHOULDextend to many verifiable domains: science, code, anywhere where checking is easier than solving!

Source: https://lnkd.in/gFytbq6T
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Hao Hoang
authorHeadline: üèÜRanked #25 Global AI Creator | üß† Senior AI Researcher & Engineer | ‚úçÔ∏è Daily AI System Design Insights | ü§ñ Building Agentic Systems, RAG & LLMs | üë• 38k+ Community
text:
You are in a Senior Machine Learning Interview at Google DeepMind. The interviewer sets a trap:

"We have a 1:1000 class imbalance for fraud detection. We applied ùò§ùò≠ùò¢ùò¥ùò¥_ùò∏ùò¶ùò™ùò®ùò©ùòµùò¥ to the ùêÇùê´ùê®ùê¨ùê¨-ùêÑùêßùê≠ùê´ùê®ùê©ùê≤ loss, but the model is still missing the hard edge cases. What do we do?"

90% of candidates walk right into the wall.

Most candidates immediately suggest aggressive oversampling (ùòöùòîùòñùòõùòå) or tuning the class weights even higher (e.g., 1:5000).

They think: "If the minority class is ignored, I just need to scream louder (higher weights) during backprop."

------
ùêìùê°ùêû ùêëùêûùêöùê•ùê¢ùê≠ùê≤:
You aren't losing because the weights are wrong. You are losing because of ùêÜùê´ùêöùêùùê¢ùêûùêßùê≠ ùêÉùê´ùê®ùê∞ùêßùê¢ùêßùê†.

Even with perfect class weights, your dataset likely contains 990,000 "easy" negatives (legitimate transactions that are obviously legit) and 1,000 "hard" positives.

In standard ùêñùêûùê¢ùê†ùê°ùê≠ùêûùêù ùêÇùê´ùê®ùê¨ùê¨-ùêÑùêßùê≠ùê´ùê®ùê©ùê≤ (ùêñùêÇùêÑ), the gradients from those 990,000 easy examples, even if individually small, sum up to dominate the update step.
 
The model spends all its capacity optimizing examples it has already learned, drowning out the signal from the difficult, subtle fraud cases.

------
The Solution: ùêìùê°ùêû ùêÑùêöùê¨ùê≤-ùêÑùê±ùêöùê¶ùê©ùê•ùêû ùêíùêÆùê©ùê©ùê´ùêûùê¨ùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêß

You don't need to re-balance the counts. You need to re-balance the difficulty.
The solution is switching from ùêñùêûùê¢ùê†ùê°ùê≠ùêûùêù ùêÇùê´ùê®ùê¨ùê¨-ùêÑùêßùê≠ùê´ùê®ùê©ùê≤ to ùêÖùê®ùêúùêöùê• ùêãùê®ùê¨ùê¨.

Focal Loss adds a modulating factor (1 ‚àí p‚Çú)·µû to the standard loss equation. 

Here is what happens in production:
- ùòêùòß ùòµùò©ùò¶ ùòÆùò∞ùò•ùò¶ùò≠ ùò™ùò¥ ùò∂ùòØùò¥ùò∂ùò≥ùò¶ (ùòèùò¢ùò≥ùò• ùòåùòπùò¢ùòÆùò±ùò≠ùò¶): The modulating factor stays near 1. The loss is unchanged. The model learns.
- ùòêùòß ùòµùò©ùò¶ ùòÆùò∞ùò•ùò¶ùò≠ ùò™ùò¥ ùò§ùò∞ùòØùòßùò™ùò•ùò¶ùòØùòµ (ùòåùò¢ùò¥ùò∫ ùòåùòπùò¢ùòÆùò±ùò≠ùò¶): The factor drops to near 0. The loss contribution is effectively "shut off."

This forces the model to stop patting itself on the back for identifying the obvious negatives and focus 100% of its gradient descent budget on the edge cases.

ùêìùê°ùêû ùêÄùêßùê¨ùê∞ùêûùê´ ùêìùê°ùêöùê≠ ùêÜùêûùê≠ùê¨ ùêòùê®ùêÆ ùêáùê¢ùê´ùêûùêù:

"ùêñùêûùê¢ùê†ùê°ùê≠ùêûùêù ùêÇùê´ùê®ùê¨ùê¨-ùêÑùêßùê≠ùê´ùê®ùê©ùê≤ solves for moderate imbalance (1:10) by balancing counts. ùêÖùê®ùêúùêöùê• ùêãùê®ùê¨ùê¨ solves for extreme imbalance (1:1000+) by balancing hardness. In a fraud scenario, I would implement ùêÖùê®ùêúùêöùê• ùêãùê®ùê¨ùê¨ with Œ≥ = 2 to down-weight the easy negatives that are currently dominating the gradient."

#MachineLearning #DeepLearning #MLEngineering #AIEngineering #NeuralNetworks #ModelOptimization

‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Andriy Burkov
authorHeadline: PhD in AI, author of üìñ The Hundred-Page Language Models Book and üìñ The Hundred-Page Machine Learning Book
text:
This paper shows how to beat models with 671 billion parameters using just 7 million parameters on hard puzzle tasks. On the ARC-AGI reasoning benchmark, this tiny model achieves 45% accuracy compared to 15.8% for DeepSeek R1 and 34.5% for OpenAI's o3-mini. On extremely difficult Sudoku puzzles with only 1,000 training examples, it reaches 87% accuracy where the previous best method managed 55%.

The method treats problem-solving as iterative refinement. The network maintains a current answer and a separate "reasoning" state, then repeatedly updates both: reason about the problem, propose a better answer, reason again, improve further. A Sudoku solver might start with a partially filled grid, update some cells, then reason again about the new constraints‚Äîgradually correcting mistakes across up to 16 refinement cycles.

The core insight is that large models fail because they generate answers in one pass, so early mistakes cascade. Breaking the problem into iterative steps, even with far less computational power, proves more effective. Training takes hours on a single GPU instead of weeks on clusters, and the model fits in 28MB instead of terabytes.

Let the article talk to you on ChapterPal: https://lnkd.in/e7aY5juJ

Download the PDF: https://lnkd.in/eGnzTphn
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Sidney Jones
authorHeadline: AI Researcher ‚Ä¢ DevOps Leader ‚Ä¢ GitHub Contributor ‚Ä¢ Technologist exploring AI-Driven Architecture, Orchestration & Clean Code Systems
text:
üí° DeepSeek-OCR: Vision+LLM Fusion for Context Compression

While most of the world is focused on LLM scaling, DeepSeek-OCR is quietly tackling a different problem ‚Äî token efficiency.

What it is:

 üß† An open-source model (‚Äúdeepseek-ai/DeepSeek-OCR‚Äù) combining visual encoders + language decoders to compress long contexts through vision-based representation.

 ‚öôÔ∏è 3B parameter architecture; open on GitHub & Hugging Face.

 üìâ Reported to achieve 5‚Äì8√ó (sometimes up to 20√ó) token savings by fusing visual perception with text recognition.

Why it matters:

- If your workflows involve archived videos, scanned docs, transcripts, or multimodal retrieval ‚Äî DeepSeek-OCR could slash compute costs and speed up RAG pipelines.

- For enterprise SaaS builders, a context-compression layer like this can be a differentiator ‚Äî faster processing, smaller payloads, lower API bills.

- In creative pipelines (think video remastering, dance-studio content, YouTube transcripts), you could extract structured insights from visuals with minimal token waste.

Caveats to test before adoption:

 ‚ö†Ô∏è At maximum compression (~20√ó), accuracy can drop (down to ~60%).

 ‚úÖ Optimal zone: <10√ó compression, ~97% accuracy (per Tom‚Äôs Hardware tests).
 üîç Enterprise deployment still requires GPU infra, quantization, and licensing checks for commercial use.

Action Pointer:

Run your own benchmark ‚Äî compare DeepSeek-OCR‚Äôs compressed output vs your current OCR + embedding pipeline. Measure:
‚è± Latency
üí∞ Token cost
üìä Accuracy

If the numbers hold, this could be a cornerstone for low-cost multimodal AI pipelines ‚Äî and a signal that context compression may soon become as crucial as model scaling.

#DeepSeekOCR
 #ArtificialIntelligence
 #ComputerVision
 #LargeLanguageModels
 #MultimodalAI
 #ContextCompression
 #VisionLanguageFusion
 #LLMOptimization
 #OpenSourceAI
 #TokenEfficiency

author: Sumanth P
authorHeadline: Machine Learning Developer Advocate | LLMs, AI Agents & RAG | Shipping Open Source AI Apps | AI Engineering
text:
Turn your laptop into a powerful RAG system!

LEANN can index and search through millions of documents while using 97% less storage than traditional solutions without accuracy loss.

LEANN achieves this through graph-based selective recomputation with high-degree preserving pruning, computing embeddings on-demand instead of storing them all.

Key Features:

üîí Privacy: Everything stays on your laptop with no cloud and no hidden terms.
ü™∂ Lightweight: Smart graph pruning and CSR format cut down both storage and memory usage.
üì¶ Portable: Move your knowledge base across devices or share it with others at minimal cost.
üìà Scalable: Handles messy personal data and agent-generated memory that often crash traditional vector DBs.
‚ú® Accurate: Provides the same search quality as heavyweight solutions while using 97% less storage.

It's 100% Open Source

Link to the Github Repo in the comments!

author: Software Architecture Guild
authorHeadline: 3¬†mil seguidores
text:
üëâ Architecture Fundamentals üëà
üí¨ I‚Äôm building a practical guide for working architects. I've consolidated the core fundamentals into one place, and I would appreciate your opinions.
Before you start drawing solutions, read this. This section walks you through how to read a system, choose an architecture style, model it, run the process, and see a complete example.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Understanding Architecture
What architecture is (and isn‚Äôt), how it differs from design, and how structure, behavior, and qualities sit under real-world constraints.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Architecture Characteristics
The ‚Äú-ilities‚Äù (such as performance, scalability, and security) are treated as primary forces that shape decisions and trade-offs. These are how you defend choices.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Architecture Styles
Monolith, microservices, event-driven, service-oriented, etc. You get strengths, weaknesses, and when each style actually fits your needs instead of copy/paste hype.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Visualizing Architecture
How to communicate architecture with views and viewpoints so that different stakeholders see what matters to them ‚Äî structure, runtime behavior, and qualities. Think ‚Äúmultiple lenses,‚Äù not one diagram.
5Ô∏è‚É£ Architecture Process
How architecture is produced: decisions, trade-offs, stakeholder concerns, alignment with business goals. This treats architecture as a repeatable process, not an act of inspiration.
6Ô∏è‚É£ Sample Architecture
A complete, end-to-end example: description, high-level views, decisions. So you can see what ‚Äúthis is our architecture‚Äù actually looks like in practice.

üìå Takeaway
This is the starting point for doing architecture like an engineer, not a stylist. Read the Fundamentals section and pressure-test your own system against it.

Read the guide to learn more: https://lnkd.in/dHnp3Q64

author: Paul Iusztin
authorHeadline: Senior AI Engineer ‚Ä¢ Founder @ Decoding AI ‚Ä¢ Author @ LLM Engineer‚Äôs Handbook ~ I ship AI products and teach you about the process.
text:
I am flying to San Francisco. This is the reading list for my 12-hour flight on AI Evals, Knowledge Graphs, LLMOps and Context Engineering I never had time to dig into.

Now I have no other choice. 

Here we go:

I will start with the LLMOps book by Abi Aryan ‚òØÔ∏é, which is probably one of the best on the topic. This one will keep me busy for a while.

Next, I will move on to some articles on evaluating RAG systems by Jason Liu:
‚Ä¢ There are only 6 RAG Evals: https://lnkd.in/digtBsDV
‚Ä¢ Levels of Complexity: RAG Apps: https://lnkd.in/dCNpctJN

Now, moving to one of my latest fantasies, Knowledge Graphs:
‚Ä¢ How to Implement Graph RAG Using Knowledge Graphs and Vector Databases: https://lnkd.in/dR2m7TpU
‚Ä¢ How to Build a Graph RAG App: https://lnkd.in/d_pHeu2p
‚Ä¢ How to Implement Knowledge Graphs and LLMs at the Enterprise Level: https://lnkd.in/djMmu33b
‚Ä¢ Primers ‚Ä¢ Graph Neural Networks: https://lnkd.in/dXZibfby
‚Ä¢ Recommendation Systems ‚Ä¢ Graph Neural Networks: https://lnkd.in/dNwKupPg

Other must-reads for AI Engineers:
‚Ä¢ Effective context engineering for AI agents: https://lnkd.in/dknFHeRF
‚Ä¢ From Notebooks to Production Server: Build AI Applications The Right Way: https://lnkd.in/d2e6WtCk (amazing piece on applying the clean architecture to AI projects by Jeremy Arancio)
‚Ä¢ Digging more into the nitty-gritty details of MCP. Nothing beats the FastMCP docs by Prefect on that.
‚Ä¢ Defeating Nondeterminism in LLM Inference: https://lnkd.in/dwmgCDrr

How do I read this on a plane? Readwise Reader is an amazing app that lets you store your reading list offline while taking notes.

Probably won‚Äôt have time to read everything, but I like making lists. 

So here you go. Enjoy!

What else would you add on AI Evals, KG or LLMOps?
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Vaibhav Srivastav
authorHeadline: ex Head of DX @ Hugging Face
text:
Kudos to OpenAI team for their guide on what makes documentation good - it's brilliant! ü•≥

Few gems that stood out:
> Make docs easy to skim ‚Üí clear titles, short paras, bullets & bold text
> Write simply ‚Üí cut jargon, avoid abbreviations, explain even ‚Äúobvious‚Äù steps
> Be broadly helpful ‚Üí docs aren‚Äôt just for experts, they‚Äôre for everyone
> Prioritise value ‚Üí solve common problems first, avoid teaching bad habits

> Above all: docs are an act of empathy ‚ù§Ô∏è

If you care about Developer Experience, you should give it a read!
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Alejandro Saucedo
authorHeadline: AI & Tech Executive @ Zalando | Advisor @ UN, EU, ACM, etc | Join 70k+ ML Newsletter
text:
Anthropic‚Äôs new Claude Skills system released last week may be more transformative than the MCP craze due to a few advantages: 

Claude Skills are opening more possibilities for lightweight, modular extensions to LLMs using simple Markdown files and optional scripts that Claude can load directly. 

These "skills" let models perform specialized tasks efficiently within a coding environment, which significantly reduces token overhead and complexity compared to MCP's heavy protocol structure. 

Although it can be argued that these two frameworks can be compatible / interchangeable in the future, it is interesting to see this wild-wild west of competing approaches to find the global optimal. 

This is a great write-up by Simon Willison which summarises both the advantages as well as some practical examples. 

Simon Willison's Deep Dive: https://lnkd.in/eD4rMh7M 
Anthropic Announcement: https://lnkd.in/eXYg6Tne 

--

If you liked this post you can join 70,000+ practitioners for weekly tutorials, resources, OSS frameworks, and MLOps events across the machine learning ecosystem: https://lnkd.in/eRBQzVcA

#ML #MachineLearning #ArtificialIntelligence #AI #MLOps #AIOps #DataOps #augmentedintelligence #deeplearning #privacy #kubernetes #datascience #python #bigdata

author: Andrew Ng
authorHeadline: Founder of DeepLearning.AI; Managing General Partner of AI Fund; Exec Chairman of LandingAI
text:
Learn to build your own voice-activated AI assistant that can execute tasks like gathering recent AI news from the web, scripting out a podcast, and using tools to put all that into a multi-speaker podcast. See our new short course: "Building Live Voice Agents with Google‚Äôs ADK (Agent Development Kit),‚Äù taught by Google‚Äôs Lavi Nigam and Sita Lakshmi Sangameswaran. 

ADK provides modular components that make it easy to build and debug agents. It also includes a built-in web interface for tracing agentic reasoning. This course illustrates these concepts via building a live voice agent that can chain actions to complete a complex task like creating a podcast. This requires maintaining context, implementing guardrails, reasoning, and handling audio streaming, while keeping latency low.

You‚Äôll learn to:
- Build voice agents that listen, reason, and respond
- Guide your agent to follow a specific workflow to accomplish a task
- Coordinate specialized agents to build an agentic podcast workflow that researches topics and produces multi-speaker audio
- Understand how to deploy an agent into production

Even if you‚Äôre not yet building voice systems, you'll find understanding how realtime agents stream data and maintain reliability useful for designing modern agentic applications.

Please join here: https://lnkd.in/ga6tD5rt
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Om Nalinde
authorHeadline: Building and Teaching AI Agents | CS @IIIT
text:
üö® BREAKING: 400,000 GPU hours later, Meta figured out why your RL training hits a wall.

The Big Problem They Solved:

> RL training felt unpredictable. Meta ran 400,000+ GPU hours of experiments and found it actually follows predictable sigmoid curves ‚Äì if you know what to measure.

Why This Matters: 

> Predict success early ‚Äì Test if your approach will scale using 1/6th the compute
> Stop wasting resources ‚Äì Some methods look good early but hit ceilings fast
> Clear recipe exists ‚Äì ScaleRL combines PipelineRL, CISPO loss, FP32 precision, smart filtering. Nothing novel, just done right.

Counterintuitive Findings:

> Bigger batches look worse initially but win at scale
> Most tweaks (curriculum, normalization) just affect speed
> Loss type and precision? Actually change your performance ceiling
> Interruptions beat length penalties

The Results: 

> They scaled to 100k GPU hours and performance matched predictions from 50k. The extrapolation held across larger models (17B√ó16 MoE), longer context (32k tokens), and multi-task training.

Bottom Line:

> Focus on asymptotic performance (A) first, efficiency (B) second. Use their sigmoid fitting to predict scalability early.
> Or just start with ScaleRL ‚Äì they did the hard work.
> This turns RL scaling from alchemy into engineering.

Paper: arxiv.org/abs/2510.13786
‚Ä¶ver m√°s

author: Sebastian Raschka, PhD
authorHeadline: ML/AI research engineer. Author of Build a Large Language Model From Scratch (amzn.to/4fqvn0D) and Ahead of AI (magazine.sebastianraschka.com), on how LLMs work and the latest developments in the field.
text:
Chapter 3 on building a symbolic verifier for LLMs from scratch is now live: https://mng.bz/lZ5B. And with this, the first 176 pages of Build A Reasoning Model (From Scratch) are now available.

This verifier is a useful method for evaluating LLMs. It's one of the more useful evaluation methods in our repertoire. In addition, it also doubles as an important component for reinforcement learning, which has become a cornerstone of LLM training in 2025. (But more on that in future chapters.)
‚Ä¶ver m√°s
